awd_titl_txt: Phase II IUCRC Villanova University: Center for Energy-Smart Electronic Systems (ES2)
awd_abstract_narration:
Data centers are an integral part of life, providing services ranging from social networking, e-commerce and entertainment to cloud infrastructures that provide storage and computing capabilities for individuals and enterprises. Data centers consume over 2% of the nation's electricity, generated mostly from fossil sources.  The Center for Energy-Smart Electronic systems (ES2) was established to develop tools and methodologies for improving the energy efficiency of electronic systems, primarily data centers. Much of the energy expended by data centers is wasted due to operating inefficiencies, including operating more servers than are needed to handle the workload and overcooling the IT equipment, or deploying sub-optimal cooling and IT technologies.  ES2?s research focusses on developing intelligent and fully automated techniques for operating data centers to match the IT and cooling resources to the workload demands, avoiding energy waste while maintaining service quality.  ES2 research benefits society by: (a) providing solutions to reduce the demand on the electrical grid and the carbon footprint and enabling the growth of data center-based services in an energy-efficient way and (b) developing human resources by training engineers and computer scientists in high-demand skills. ES2?s research therefore enables the nation to maintain competitive, agile and energy-efficient cyber services and infrastructures.

The goal of ES2 research is to develop systematic methodologies for operating electronic systems, including data centers, as dynamic self-sensing and regulating cognitive systems that are predictive and verified in real time. At the Villanova site, algorithms and systems are being developed to enhance and control cooling and to assist expert system schedulers being developed at our partner site to schedule or migrate workload in a holistic manner in order to achieve optimal energy consumption. Advanced strategies for cooling data centers using hybrid air-liquid cooling and single and two-phase liquid cooling are being developed and optimized.  These advanced cooling methods anticipate ever increasing thermal densities in data center equipment. Our research is leading to the development of improved methods and metrics for utilizing Dynamic Hybrid Cooling Systems which can be used to deliver efficient on-demand cooling where and when it is needed.  The Villanova site is investigating methods for the conversion of Waste Heat from electrical power consumed in a data center to useful Energy.  More than 90% of electrical power supplied to a data center is dissipated as waste heat, hence our research will have significant impact on the overall energy sustainability of data center systems.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

por.por_cntn:
NSF Center for Energy Smart Electronic Systems (ES2)—an Industry/University Cooperative Research Center

Phase II NSF Outcomes Report for Villanova University

During Phase II, the Villanova site of ES2 has focused on three main research areas:  (1.) research on understanding the environmental impact of data centers; (2.) research on understanding and modeling chip and server level thermal management; and (3.) research on understanding and modeling system and room level thermal management.  Project in these three areas are summarized here.

1. Research on Decreasing the Environmental Impacts and Resource Burden of Data Centers

This project quantifies the environmental burden associated with data center facilities and strategies to mitigate this burden. The areas of burden are primarily water stress and carbon footprint. The following three figures provide an indication of some of the results achieved from the funding through the ES2 center during the Phase II period.

Figure 1. We explored which counties in the contiguous U.S. provide the maximum benefit for switching from grid power to on-site renewables. The blue dots indicate those counties that contain the highest benefit in reducing carbon footprint and/or water stress. Why is this important?   We were able to develop a method for geographically mapping potential data center sites that would benefit from use of renewable energy.  It is clear that employing on-site renewables has the greatest benefits in a small subset of counties in the contiguous U.S.

Figure 2. We created an experimental test rig for recovering waste heat from data center equipment and increasing its temperature to create more possibilities for reusing the waste heat to conserve energy for non-data center applications. One key element of this rig is a refrigerant-air heat exchanger. We created a model for this component and compared it to experimental results.  Why is this important?   98% of the electrical power supplied to a data center is eventually dissipated as heat.  If it is possible to recover and re-use that waste heat, the overall energy efficiency can be increased, thus reducing energy waste.

Figure 3. Airside economization refers to allowing outside air directly into the data center, whereas waterside economization involves releasing some of the heat from the chilled water loop prior to entering the chiller.   Why is this important?  The above figure shows the reduction in carbon footprint and water scarcity impact when implementing airside and/or waterside economization in data centers in four U.S. states. 

2. Research on Increasing the Cooling Performance and Efficiency of Air- and Liquid-Cooled Data Centers

This large experimental and computational modeling project aims to understand the physical behavior of data center cooling systems using experimental laboratory testing in order to develop methods to improve their performance and to model their behavior.   

Figure 4.  (a.) Experiment schematic; (b.) Temperature response due to a step change in water temperature. We performed an extensive experimental study to characterize how water-to-air heat exchangers respond to time-dependent changes in their in the flow rate or temperature of the air or liquid streams.  We developed a mathematical model that is able to accurately simulate the temperature response of the heat exchanger under the conditions where the water temperature entering the heat exchanger changes with time.   Why is this important?   These types of heat exchangers are at the heart of most air and liquid cooling systems for data center electronics.  

Figure 5.  (a.) Typical cold plate geometries used in single phase cooling; (b.) Cold plate thermal resistance comparing data to traditional and new model

Direct to chip cooling of CPUs and GPUs is accomplished by attaching a “cold plate” onto the device and circulating water through the cold plate to absorb and remove the heat.  Fig. 5(a) shows a typical cold plate and a photo of an actual skived fin array.  Figure 5(b.) show plots of literature data for thermal resistance compared to the traditional thermal resistance model and the new cross-flow heat exchanger model.  Why is this important?   Liquid cooling systems using water have become increasingly important as the limits of cooling with air are being reached.

Figure 6.  (a.) Two-phase air-to-refrigerant evaporator showing the refrigerant flow boiling occurring as a result of absorbing heat from the heated air stream; (b.) Air inlet and exit temperatures.

We performed an extensive experimental study to characterize how refrigerant-to-air heat exchangers respond to time-dependent changes in their in the flow rate or temperature of the air or liquid streams.  Why is this important?   Modeling time-dependent boiling in the heat exchanger is complex and requires physical understanding that requires detailed experimental data and a robust mathematical model.    These types of “evaporators” may be used in rear-door heat exchangers and other applications to absorb and remove heat from an air stream whose temperature may change with time as a result of time-dependent electrical loads in the equipment such as servers.

Project in these three areas are summarized here.
1. Research on Decreasing the Environmental Impacts and Resource Burden of Data Centers


This project quantifies the environmental burden associated with data center facilities and strategies to mitigate this burden. The areas of burden are primarily water stress and carbon footprint. Figure 1. We explored which counties in the contiguous U.S. provide the maximum benefit for switching from grid power to on-site renewables. Theabove figure shows the reduction in carbon footprint and water scarcity impact when implementing airside and/or waterside economization in data centers in four U.S. states.

Figure 5(b.) show plots of literature data for thermal resistance compared to the traditional thermal resistance model and the new cross-flow heat exchanger model. Why is this important? Liquid cooling systems using water have become increasingly important as the limits of cooling with air are being reached.
